study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of budesonide nasal irrigation (BNI) in managing Chronic Rhinosinusitis (CRS).
results_summary: BNI showed better outcomes than saline nasal irrigation (SNI) in improving SNOT-22 and Lund-Kennedy Endoscopy scores, with no significant differences in intraocular pressure or serum cortisol levels, indicating both efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: 1464 patients with Chronic Rhinosinusitis (CRS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine factors of nasal irrigation (NI) that increase the risk of chronic otorrhea (CO) in children with tympanostomy tubes (TT).
results_summary: A fast rate of NI administration was linked to higher CO risk, while no difference was found in NI frequency or volume. Immediate discharge and TT insertion under local anesthesia were also associated with CO.
population_specificity: Children under 18 with bilateral tympanostomy tubes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (volume ≤5 mL was noted as unused in CO cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hypertonic saline nasal irrigation and gargling (HSNIG) improves symptom resolution and other outcomes in individuals with suspected or confirmed COVID-19.
results_summary: HSNIG showed no significant benefit in symptom resolution or time to improvement compared to the control group (ablution with tap water). The intervention was not effective for COVID-19 when started within five days of symptom onset.
population_specificity: Adults with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 in Pakistan.
effective_dosage: 2.6% hypertonic saline solution for nasal irrigation and gargling.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were measured within the study period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of nasal irrigation in preventing SARS-CoV-2 transmission and alleviating upper respiratory tract infection symptoms in individuals with long COVID.
results_summary: The study suggests nasal irrigation may reduce viral presence in the upper respiratory tract, enhance mucociliary clearance, and potentially lessen symptom severity and transmission rates. It concludes that saline nasal irrigation is an effective, safe, and convenient strategy for various age groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with long COVID experiencing upper respiratory tract symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand family perceptions of nasal irrigation in hospitalized children after an educational intervention mediated by instructional therapeutic play (ITP).
results_summary: The study found that ITP transformed nasal irrigation from a distressing to an enjoyable procedure for children and their families, improving understanding and acceptance of the process. ITP was evaluated as an essential and stimulating method that facilitated the procedure for both children and families.
population_specificity: Family members of hospitalized children aged 3-6 years in São Paulo, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the presence of microplastics in nasal irrigation methods and evaluate human exposure to them.
results_summary: The study found varying levels of microplastics in nasal irrigation products, with the highest exposure in nasal wash bottles. Significant differences in microplastic exposure were noted between different product types.
population_specificity: Not specified (samples included nasal wash bottles, seawater sprays, and syringes for nasal irrigation).
effective_dosage: Not specified (samples were assessed per product type).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of hydrogen-rich saline (HRS) versus normal saline (NS) for nasal irrigation in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) after surgery.
results_summary: HRS nasal irrigation was more effective than NS, showing lower VAS scores, higher rates of clinical cure, and faster mucosal healing. No adverse reactions were reported in either group.
population_specificity: 61 patients with CRS who underwent functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency: once a week for 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of various nasal irrigation solutions compared to normal saline in postoperative FESS patients with chronic rhinosinusitis and nasal polyposis.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation with various solutions, particularly budesonide, showed significant improvements in patient-reported symptoms and endoscopic scores compared to normal saline, though high heterogeneity and potential publication bias were noted.
population_specificity: Postoperative FESS patients with chronic rhinosinusitis and nasal polyposis (CRSwNP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nasal irrigation with saline, povidone iodine (PVP-I), or intranasal corticosteroids (INCS) could reduce SARS-CoV-2 nasopharyngeal viral load (NVL) and transmissibility.
results_summary: Saline-based nasal irrigation showed positive effects in reducing NVL, with benefits noted in earlier time to negative PCR and greater decline in NVL during early study time points. PVP-I had mixed results, while no studies were found on INCS.
population_specificity: Individuals with SARS-CoV-2 infection (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (isotonic and hypertonic saline mediums were used, with some studies including additives).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of an evidence-based nursing program for nasal irrigation on postoperative recovery in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) after endoscopic sinus surgery.
results_summary: The study found that evidence-based nasal irrigation nursing significantly improved SNOT-20, VAS, Lund-Mackay CT, and LKES scores compared to conventional nursing, with the experimental group showing a higher overall effective rate (90.62% vs. 16.43%), though the difference in treatment effect was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 66 patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) who underwent endoscopic sinus surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to standardize the application of nasal irrigation (NI) in healthcare practice, improve the prevention and treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS), and facilitate further research on local CRS treatment.
results_summary: NI is a beneficial low-risk treatment for CRS, with isotonic saline being the most accepted flushing solution and large-volume low-pressure flushing bottles showing the best effect and patient tolerance. Further research is needed on alternative flushing solutions, techniques, and treatment courses.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on isotonic saline and large-volume low-pressure flushing devices).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of physiological seawater nasal irrigation (PSNI) in reducing viral shedding duration and symptom changes in children with mild or asymptomatic Omicron infection.
results_summary: PSNI significantly reduced the duration of viral shedding compared to the control group, particularly in unvaccinated children, but showed no clear benefit in reducing nasal symptoms beyond the control group's natural improvement.
population_specificity: 403 children (median age 5.59 years) with mild or asymptomatic Omicron BA.2 variant infection in Shanghai, China.

study_goal: To investigate whether nasal irrigation with 3% hypertonic saline reduces symptom duration and nucleic acid conversion time in adults infected with the Omicron variant of COVID-19.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation significantly shortened nucleic acid negative conversion time but did not improve symptom disappearance time. Subgroup analysis confirmed similar benefits in treatment-naïve patients.
population_specificity: Adults with asymptomatic, mild, or moderate Omicron infection at Shandong Public Health Clinical Center.
effective_dosage: 3% hypertonic saline nasal irrigation (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether nasal irrigation and oral rinse with 5% sodium bicarbonate solution could enhance virus clearance in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that patients using sodium bicarbonate nasal irrigation and oral rinse had a significantly shorter negative conversion time (1.63 days) and hospitalization time (7.7 days vs. 12.53 days in controls), suggesting improved virus clearance.
population_specificity: 55 COVID-19 patients with mild or moderate symptoms.
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were measured daily until negative conversion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saline nasal irrigation, combined with LhQw Granules, could reduce symptom duration and nucleic acid conversion time in children infected with the Omicron variant.
results_summary: Saline nasal irrigation significantly reduced nucleic acid conversion time compared to the routine group, though fever and cough duration were similar across groups. Lymphocyte counts improved in the saline groups, with no significant difference between isotonic and hypertonic saline.
population_specificity: Children (7.26 ± 3.15 years old) with asymptomatic, mild, or moderate Omicron variant infection.
effective_dosage: 3% hypertonic saline and isotonic saline nasal irrigation (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of hypertonic seawater nasal irrigation (HSS-Plus) in reducing viral load and alleviating nasal symptoms in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that HSS-Plus significantly reduced viral load (93.6% of patients showed >0.5 log10 decrease) and improved nasal symptoms (mean VAS score dropped from 27.57 to 6.73) with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients admitted to Sotiria Hospital, Athens, Greece.
study_duration: Up to 10 days or until hospital discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of chlorine dioxide (ClO2) for nasal irrigation as a potential therapy for respiratory infectious diseases, particularly COVID-19.
results_summary: The study suggested that 25-50 ppm ClO2 is an appropriate concentration for nasal irrigation to treat COVID-19, based on preliminary safety and efficacy evaluations, but further verification is needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human use implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of high-volume budesonide nasal irrigation versus normal saline irrigation in post-ESS chronic rhinosinusitis patients, focusing on symptom improvement and safety parameters like serum cortisol levels and intraocular pressure.
results_summary: The study found that high-volume budesonide irrigation significantly improved SNOT-22 and Lund-Kennedy endoscopic scores compared to normal saline, with 72.73% of case nasal cavities showing total improvement versus 57.57% in controls. Safety assessments indicated no significant adverse effects.
population_specificity: 66 chronic rhinosinusitis patients (50 male, 16 female; mean age 33 years) with prior failed medical therapy, post-endoscopic sinus surgery.
effective_dosage: 1 mg of budesonide irrigation twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the clinical efficacy of nasal irrigation with various solutions for adults with allergic rhinitis (AR).
results_summary: The study will analyze and summarize the efficacy of different nasal irrigation solutions for AR, with results to be published in a peer-reviewed journal. The abstract does not yet provide specific findings.
population_specificity: Adults with allergic rhinitis (AR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of hypertonic saline (3%) and isotonic saline (0.9%) nasal irrigation on symptom improvement and mucosal normalization in patients after functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS).
results_summary: Hypertonic saline nasal irrigation showed significant improvement in SNOT20 and VAS scores, as well as better normalization of sino-nasal mucosa compared to isotonic saline. Both groups showed similar improvements in mucociliary clearance and resolution of postoperative crustings.
population_specificity: 156 patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (with or without nasal polyposis) resistant to conservative management, who underwent FESS.
effective_dosage: Group 1: 3% hypertonic saline; Group 2: 0.9% isotonic saline (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at weeks 1, 3, and 6 post-operatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight a rare case of mitral valve infective endocarditis linked to nasal irrigation in a patient with chronic allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: The study reported a case of mitral valve infective endocarditis associated with nasal irrigation, demonstrating persistent vegetation despite antibiotic therapy. It emphasized the need for clinicians to consider nasal hygiene in endocarditis cases and advise against nasal irrigation if epistaxis is present.
population_specificity: A 49-year-old African American woman with chronic allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of saline nasal irrigation (SNI) in reducing COVID-19 infection rates, illness severity, and community transmission.
results_summary: The study suggests SNI may decrease COVID-19 infection rates, lower illness severity, and mitigate community transmission due to NaCl's antiviral effects and mechanical cleansing. However, more concentrated research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how nasal saline irrigation disperses through altered nasal cavities post-FESS surgery using computational fluid dynamics (CFD).
results_summary: The study found that saline penetration into the maxillary sinus was influenced by ostium size, reducing coverage in other sinuses. Head position affected saline residual, particularly in the frontal sinuses, and patients without a nasal septum experienced limited posterior sinus penetration.
population_specificity: Post-FESS patients (specific example: 27-year-old male).
effective_dosage: Not specified (squeeze bottle with realistic squeeze profile).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of corticosteroid nasal irrigation, saline irrigation, and no treatment in restoring smell sensation in COVID-19 patients with olfactory loss.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in smell sensation scores among the three groups at any follow-up period. Corticosteroid irrigation showed a temporary improvement in quality-of-life scores at 1 week, but all groups demonstrated similar recovery times (median 3 weeks).
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients with new-onset smell loss (n=222).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) nasal irrigation for chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) recovery after endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS).
results_summary: The study outlines a protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess TCM nasal irrigation's efficacy and safety, but no specific results are provided in the abstract. The planned outcomes include efficacy, symptom scores, and endoscopic/radiological findings.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) who underwent endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of theophylline added to saline nasal irrigation (SNI) compared with placebo for treating COVID-19-related olfactory dysfunction (OD).
results_summary: The study found that 59% of participants in the theophylline arm reported at least slight improvement in olfactory function compared to 43% in the placebo arm, but the difference was not statistically significant. Subjective assessments suggested potential benefits, but objective measures like UPSIT scores showed no significant difference between groups.
population_specificity: Adults with OD persisting for 3 to 12 months following suspected COVID-19 infection, residing in Missouri or Illinois.
effective_dosage: 400 mg theophylline dissolved in saline rinse, used twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of budesonide nasal irrigation compared to saline nasal irrigation as an adjunct treatment for allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Budesonide nasal irrigation significantly improved SNOT-22 scores and endoscopic nasal examination findings (e.g., reduced nasal mucosa edema and secretions) compared to saline irrigation, but neither treatment significantly affected blood eosinophil counts.
population_specificity: 99 patients diagnosed with allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the sinus distribution of high-volume nasal irrigation versus nasal spray in unoperated chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) patients.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation showed significantly higher fluorescein staining scores in sinuses compared to nasal spray, particularly in the maxillary and anterior ethmoid sinuses, but minimal effect in the frontal and sphenoid sinuses.
population_specificity: Forty patients undergoing endoscopic sinus surgery for CRS, with 38 meeting inclusion criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term effects of budesonide nasal irrigation (BNI) on reducing oral steroid and antibiotic use while improving symptoms and endoscopic findings in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps (CRSwNP) and asthma.
results_summary: BNI significantly reduced oral steroid and antibiotic dosages, improved nasal endoscopy scores until 12 months, and enhanced subjective symptom scores in patients with CRSwNP and asthma.
population_specificity: 33 patients with CRSwNP and well-controlled asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent of nasal irrigation in non-operated sinuses and compare the effectiveness of two head positions (standing-leaning-forward and head-down forward) during irrigation.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation reached non-operated sinuses more effectively in the head-down forward (HDF) position, particularly in the olfactory cleft, frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoid sinus, with significant differences compared to the standing-leaning-forward (SLF) position. Overall, irrigation coverage was 70.37% in HDF versus 45.06% in SLF.
population_specificity: Cadaveric heads with non-operated sinuses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical effects of Biyuan Tongqiao granules combined with saline nasal irrigation on chronic sinusitis, including impacts on CT scores, adverse reactions, and symptom improvement.
results_summary: The experimental group (Biyuan Tongqiao granules + nasal irrigation) showed significantly better clinical effects, lower CT scores, faster recovery, and reduced pain and symptom scores compared to the control group (nasal irrigation alone), with no adverse reactions reported.
population_specificity: 90 patients with chronic sinusitis admitted between June 2019 and June 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish evidence-based clinical practice guidelines for nasal irrigation in adult patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS), addressing knowledge gaps, practice variations, and clinical concerns.
results_summary: The study found that nasal irrigation is recommended as a first-line treatment for CRS, with demonstrated clinical effectiveness supported by robust evidence. The guideline developed 11 evidence-based recommendations, focusing on solution types, therapeutic effectiveness, and the role of additional medications.
population_specificity: Adult patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and outcomes of daily hypertonic saline irrigation versus saline/xylitol for treating pediatric chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
results_summary: Hypertonic saline irrigation significantly improved quality of life scores in pediatric CRS patients, while saline/xylitol showed no additional benefits and had lower tolerance and compliance. The study concluded hypertonic saline is safe and effective as a baseline treatment for pediatric CRS.
population_specificity: 125 children diagnosed with chronic rhinosinusitis.
effective_dosage: Twice-daily hypertonic saline or saline/xylitol irrigation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nasal irrigation reduces or prevents nasal complications, such as dysosmia, epistaxis, and nasal adhesions, after endoscopic transsphenoidal pituitary adenoma resection.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation significantly reduced early postoperative complications like epistaxis and nasal adhesions at 1 month and improved olfactory disturbances at 3 months compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 60 patients who underwent endoscopic transsphenoidal pituitary adenoma resection at a tertiary hospital.
effective_dosage: 50 mL of 2% saline solution (first week), then 50 mL of 0.9% normal saline solution (subsequent weeks), administered bilaterally.
study_duration: 1 week of 2% saline irrigation, followed by continued irrigation with 0.9% saline (total follow-up: 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of hypertonic alkaline nasal irrigation (HANI) on reducing nasopharyngeal SARS-CoV-2 viral load in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant decrease in nasopharyngeal viral load (NVL) in patients using HANI combined with hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) compared to HCQ alone, suggesting HANI may be effective for COVID-19 treatment. The difference in NVL reduction between the two groups was significant (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: 60 COVID-19 patients divided into two groups (HCQ alone vs. HCQ + HANI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of nasal irrigation, alone and combined with subcutaneous immunotherapy, on symptom improvement and recurrence rates in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis and allergic rhinitis after endoscopic sinus surgery.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation combined with subcutaneous immunotherapy significantly reduced recurrence rates, improved nasal mucosa health, and lowered inflammatory markers compared to medication alone. Nasal irrigation alone also showed benefits in reducing certain inflammatory markers but was less effective than the combined treatment.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with chronic rhinosinusitis and allergic rhinitis who underwent endoscopic sinus surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the occurrence of nasal septal perforation as a rare complication of self-administered nasal irrigation after endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS).
results_summary: The study reported three cases of nasal septal perforation following self-nasal irrigation post-ESS, suggesting that improper irrigation techniques may lead to this rare complication. The authors emphasize the need for patient education and regular nasal septum checks.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bilateral ESS and bilateral inferior turbinectomy for chronic rhinosinusitis and allergic rhinitis.
study_duration: Two and a half months post-operation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the validity of intraoperative antiseptic treatment (octenidine solution) during endoscopic sinus surgery and its impact on postoperative outcomes, particularly crusting reduction.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in postoperative crusting (measured by the Lund-Kennedy scale) in the octenidine-treated group compared to saline. Intraoperative lavage with either solution reduced positive postoperative cultures relative to preoperative ones.
population_specificity: 55 patients with chronic sinusitis undergoing surgical treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (flushing with octenidine solution vs. saline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal head tilt position for nasal irrigation to improve sinonasal coverage, residence time, and shear stresses using computational fluid dynamics.
results_summary: The 45° backward head tilt position was most effective for delivering irrigation to the ethmoid, frontal, and sphenoid sinuses, while head tilt had minimal impact on maxillary sinus delivery. Wall shear stresses varied locally but showed marginal differences in mean stress across tilt positions.
population_specificity: Healthy 25-year-old Asian female
effective_dosage: 150 mL liquid via squeeze bottle through the left nostril for 2 s with 0.1 s acceleration/deceleration time

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of licorice extract nasal irrigation (LNI) compared to corticosteroid nasal irrigation (CNI) and saline nasal irrigation (SNI) in treating allergic rhinitis (AR).
results_summary: LNI showed superior efficacy in improving nasal symptoms (blockage, rhinorrhea, sneezing, pruritus, postnasal discharge, olfactory disturbance) and nasal resistance compared to CNI and SNI, with no reported side effects or complications. Both LNI and CNI significantly improved turbinate hypertrophy, while SNI did not.
population_specificity: 60 participants diagnosed with allergic rhinitis.
effective_dosage: Nasal irrigation once daily (specific extract dosage not detailed).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of nasal irrigation with sodium hyaluronate and surfactant solutions on mucociliary clearance time in patients with mild persistent allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Both surfactant and sodium hyaluronate nasal irrigation significantly improved mucociliary clearance times compared to isotonic saline, with surfactant showing superior efficacy. The surfactant group had significantly lower post-treatment mucociliary clearance times than both the control and sodium hyaluronate groups.
population_specificity: 120 patients diagnosed with mild persistent allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical benefits of nasal irrigation with Houttuynia cordata preparation for rhinosinusitis patients, focusing on symptom improvement and recovery rates.
results_summary: The study conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to evaluate the efficacy of nasal irrigation with HC preparation, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The findings will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.
population_specificity: Rhinosinusitis patients, including those recovering from endoscopic sinus surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic and prophylactic value of saline water gargling and nasal irrigation in the context of COVID-19, drawing on previous evidence from influenza studies and post-hoc analysis of the ELVIS trial.
results_summary: The study suggests that nasal irrigation and saline gargling are simple, economical, and feasible strategies with potential infection control benefits, though direct evidence for SARS-CoV-2 is limited. Previous work on influenza and post-hoc analysis of ELVIS supports their applicability.
population_specificity: Not specified (general applicability inferred from traditional and recent studies).

study_goal: To compare the treatment outcomes of different concentrations of nasal irrigation (3% NaCl vs. 0.9% NaCl) as adjuvant therapy in adults with intermittent allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Both concentrations of nasal irrigation significantly improved nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, inferior turbinate size, and PNEFR, with 3% NaCl showing earlier improvement in PNEFR after one week. No significant differences were found between the two concentrations for most parameters.
population_specificity: Adults with intermittent allergic rhinitis (80 patients, 40 per group).
effective_dosage: 3% NaCl and 0.9% NaCl nasal irrigation (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different nasal irrigation devices in treating various types of rhinosinusitis based on patient experiences.
results_summary: High-volume nasal irrigation devices were most effective in clearing secretions in acute viral rhinosinusitis, chronic rhinosinusitis without nasal polyps, and acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, and in reducing post-nasal drip in acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. No significant differences were found among devices for chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps.
population_specificity: Patients with acute viral rhinosinusitis (18%), acute bacterial rhinosinusitis (13%), chronic rhinosinusitis without nasal polyps (37%), and chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps (32%).
study_duration: Survey conducted between November 2017 and December 2019 (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a nasal irrigation technique developed for managing cystic fibrosis and bronchiolitis in children over 6 months, emphasizing proper execution and safety.
results_summary: The study proposed a standardized nasal irrigation technique involving a 30° upward inclined plane, continuous flow spray (6mL per nostril), and repeated steps until satisfactory patency was achieved. The method was designed to improve adherence and effectiveness in young children.
population_specificity: Children over 6 months with cystic fibrosis or bronchiolitis.
effective_dosage: 6mL per nostril, repeated until patency achieved.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of combining oral desloratadine citrate disodium with physiological seawater nasal irrigation in treating intermittent allergic rhinitis, focusing on its impact on serum inflammatory factors and peripheral blood Th1 and Th2 responses.
results_summary: The study found that the combination treatment significantly improved symptoms, reduced serum IgE and inflammatory markers (IL-4, IL-6, IL-13), increased IFN-γ levels, and lowered the one-year recurrence rate compared to desloratadine alone. The observation group showed more pronounced improvements in balancing Th1/Th2 responses and reducing inflammation.
population_specificity: 100 patients with intermittent allergic rhinitis admitted to a hospital between January 2018 and January 2020.
effective_dosage: Not specified (physiological seawater nasal irrigation frequency/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of nasal lavage with saline solution versus xylitol solution in improving nasal symptoms post-endonasal endoscopic surgery.
results_summary: The xylitol group showed significant improvement in pain relief and nasal symptom reduction compared to the saline group, with statistically significant results (p < 0.001). The saline group also improved but to a lesser extent.
population_specificity: 52 patients with chronic rhinosinusitis undergoing endonasal endoscopic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of hypertonic saline and isotonic saline in treating rhinosinusitis to guide clinical nasal irrigation practices for chronic rhinosinusitis.
results_summary: Hypertonic saline was significantly more effective than isotonic saline in improving nasal symptoms (e.g., secretion, congestion, headache) and mucociliary clearance but showed no significant difference in smell improvement or radiologic scores. Hypertonic saline had greater minor adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic rhinosinusitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of saline nasal irrigation (SNI) in infants and children with acute rhinopharyngitis.
results_summary: SNI showed benefits for rhinological symptoms but no significant improvement in respiratory symptoms or overall health status. It reduced the need for other treatments, including antibiotics, and long-term use decreased acute rhinosinusitis incidence.
population_specificity: Infants ≥3 months and children ≤12 years with acute rhinopharyngitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the subjective and clinical response to budesonide buffered hypertonic saline nasal irrigation versus hypertonic saline nasal irrigation alone in patients with allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvement in SNOT-22, VAS, and modified Lund-Kennedy scores, but the budesonide group had significantly better improvement in SNOT-22 and VAS scores. The clinical response difference between groups was not significant.
population_specificity: 52 patients diagnosed with allergic rhinitis.
effective_dosage: Buffered hypertonic saline nasal irrigation with a placebo respule or budesonide respule (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: To compare the clinical response of nasal irrigation with 1% compounded budesonide drops or betamethasone cream versus corticosteroid nasal sprays in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis.
results_summary: Corticosteroid nasal irrigation improved the Lund-Kennedy endoscopic score, particularly in patients with nasal polyps and previous surgery, and showed greater subjective improvement and fewer exacerbations than nasal sprays, though with more adverse events. 1% compounded budesonide drops were more effective and safer than betamethasone cream, especially at higher doses (1000 µg).
population_specificity: 257 patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (108 using nasal irrigation, 149 using nasal sprays).
effective_dosage: 1% compounded budesonide drops (500 µg and 1000 µg doses), betamethasone cream (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different frontal sinusotomy techniques (Draf IIa, IIb, and III) in delivering nasal irrigation to the frontal sinus.
results_summary: Draf III provided the greatest distribution of nasal irrigation (90.7%), followed by Draf IIb (81.3%) and Draf IIa (50.1%). Vertex positioning and increased irrigation volume showed trends toward improved distribution but were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Unfixed human cadaver heads (8 specimens, average age 78 ± 12.3 years, 62.5% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nasal irrigation with a hypertonic sea-water solution supplemented with algae extracts as an add-on treatment for allergic rhinitis in children and adolescents.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation significantly improved symptom control (measured by CARAT and CARATKids scores) and reduced medication use (measured by TSMS) compared to regular treatment alone, particularly in patients over 12 years old. The MASK data showed comparable allergic symptoms between groups, but the nasal irrigation group had fewer days using symptomatic treatment.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with allergic rhinitis (76 patients, aged <12 and >12 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the risk of bacterial contamination in nasal irrigation bottles and correlate it with endoscopic findings in post-sinonasal surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found significant bacterial contamination in nasal irrigation bottles and patients' nasal cavities, primarily Pseudomonas sp., but no clinical evidence of infection was observed endoscopically. Contamination increased significantly by the second week but stabilized thereafter.
population_specificity: Post-sinonasal surgery patients (27 participants, divided into case and control groups).
effective_dosage: Nasal irrigation three times per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the scientific evidence on the efficacy, mechanism of action, preparation, indications, and therapeutic advantages of nasal irrigation for sinonasal symptom relief.
results_summary: Recent evidence supports the benefits of nasal irrigation for relieving sinonasal symptoms, though earlier studies were poorly controlled and contributed to confusion about its efficacy. The review highlights its clinical applications and efficacy based on current literature.
population_specificity: Not specified (general sinonasal symptom sufferers implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize nasal irrigation efficiency by comparing large-volume manual/gravity pressure irrigation with small-volume continuous spraying using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations.
results_summary: Large-volume irrigation (15 mL/s) covered all nasal zones rapidly with strong shear stress and prolonged contact time, while continuous spraying (3 mL/s) covered areas more slowly with lower shear stress and shorter contact time. CFD simulations provided objective parameters to determine the most effective irrigation mode.
population_specificity: Healthy adult (based on high-resolution CT scan used for 3D model construction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of amphotericin B nasal irrigation on nasal polyp recurrence and the association of serum IgE with fungal presence in nasal polyps.
results_summary: Amphotericin B improved CT scan scores but did not significantly reduce polyp recurrence compared to saline irrigation. Serum IgE levels showed a significant association with treatment response and fungal presence.
population_specificity: Adult patients with nasal polyps, excluding those under 18, with granulomatous diseases, immunosuppression, invasive fungal sinusitis, or pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nasal irrigation devices based on patient and physician experiences.
results_summary: High-pressure large-volume nasal irrigation devices showed significantly higher symptom improvement in multiple domains but had a higher incidence of retained fluid in the sinuses compared to low-pressure devices. The study supports nasal irrigation as effective for symptom relief with good compliance and minimal side effects.
population_specificity: Patients aged 5-81 years (mean 45.46 ± 17.19), roughly equal gender distribution (48.6% male, 51.4% female).
study_duration: Survey conducted between November 2017 and October 2018 (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sodium hyaluronate administered via nasal irrigation with saline in the post-operative period following functional endoscopic sinus surgery for chronic rhinosinusitis.
results_summary: Both objective (endoscopic appearance) and subjective (patient-reported satisfaction) measurements were significantly better in the group receiving saline plus sodium hyaluronate compared to the group receiving only normal saline. Sodium hyaluronate was found to be a useful adjunct to nasal saline irrigation in the early post-operative period.
population_specificity: 56 consecutive patients who underwent functional endoscopic sinus surgery for chronic rhinosinusitis without polyps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of different concentrations of saline irrigation (isotonic vs. hypertonic) as adjunctive treatment for allergic rhinitis using a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that saline irrigation significantly improved symptoms (lower VAS and RQLQ scores) and effectiveness compared to no irrigation, with hypertonic saline showing better results than isotonic saline in reducing nasal symptoms and signs and increasing effectiveness.
population_specificity: 1,457 patients with allergic rhinitis across 14 randomized controlled trials.
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations mentioned: isotonic and hypertonic saline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of hypertonic saline nasal irrigation (HSNI) in improving nasal symptoms, quality of life, and reducing oral antihistamine use in children with allergic rhinitis (AR).
results_summary: HSNI improved nasal symptom scores and reduced antihistamine use compared to baseline, and showed better symptom relief than isotonic saline nasal irrigation (ISNI), though antihistamine use and adverse effects were similar between HSNI and ISNI groups.
population_specificity: Children with allergic rhinitis (AR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and potential benefits of hypertonic saline nasal irrigation and gargling (HSNIG) compared to standard care in reducing symptom duration, viral shedding, and transmission in adults with viral upper respiratory tract infections (URTI).
results_summary: The study found that HSNIG reduced illness duration by 1.9 days, decreased over-the-counter medication use by 36%, lowered household transmission by 35%, and reduced viral shedding by ≥0.5 log10/day, with high acceptability (87%) and perceived symptom improvement (93%).
population_specificity: Healthy adults within 48 hours of URTI onset.
effective_dosage: Not specified (hypertonic saline preparation method described but exact concentration/frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Until well for two days or a maximum of 14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically assess the clinical efficacy of nasal irrigation for chronic rhinosinusitis patients after functional endoscopic sinus surgery.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation with normal saline and various solutions was effective in reducing symptom and endoscopic scores, but no significant difference was found between different solutions. The study concluded that nasal irrigation is effective, though evidence is limited.
population_specificity: Chronic rhinosinusitis patients after functional endoscopic sinus surgery (331 participants across 5 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of 200 μg/mL amphotericin B nasal irrigation as an adjuvant therapy after functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
results_summary: The study found that while AMB nasal irrigation significantly improved sinonasal symptoms (TWSNOT-22 scores) within the AMB group, there was no significant difference in outcomes between the AMB and saline irrigation groups. Other measures (endoscopic score, smell test, saccharine transit test, bacterial culture rate) also showed no significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with CRS who had undergone FESS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of buffered hypertonic saline (BHS) versus normal saline solution (NSS) in reducing nasal symptoms and improving nasal cytology counts, quality of life, and sleep quality in children with seasonal allergic rhinitis (SAR).
results_summary: BHS significantly improved total symptom scores, reduced nasal cytology counts (neutrophils and eosinophils), and enhanced quality of life compared to NSS. Both solutions improved sleep quality, though NSS showed a slightly greater effect in this domain.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-13 years with seasonal allergic rhinitis and a Total 5 Symptom Score (T5SS) ≥5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of 3.0% saline nasal irrigation alone versus combined with budesonide nasal spray for vasomotor rhinitis (VMR) and explore long-term outcomes and underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation combined with budesonide showed superior long-term efficacy in reducing symptoms and improving quality of life compared to either treatment alone. Saline irrigation alone showed delayed but significant benefits by the third month, while budesonide alone had limited long-term effects.
population_specificity: 101 patients with vasomotor rhinitis from Huashan Hospital of Fudan University.
effective_dosage: 3.0% saline nasal irrigation at 40°C (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of a surfactant-added saline nasal irrigation solution in normal subjects, focusing on its effects on olfactory function and congestion.
results_summary: Surfactant nasal irrigation led to a statistically significant but marginal reduction in smell identification test scores and increased reports of moderate or severe congestion compared to saline. A small subset experienced clinically meaningful olfactory reduction, which appeared reversible.
population_specificity: Normal volunteers without active rhinitis symptoms or non-normosmic smell test results.
study_duration: 3 weeks (1 week per treatment phase with a 1-week washout).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current evidence on nasal irrigation's effectiveness and clinical relevance for treating various sinonasal conditions, particularly in children.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation appears effective for acute and chronic sinonasal conditions, but most studies have methodological flaws. Standardization of methods and large multicenter studies are needed to confirm its real relevance.
population_specificity: Primarily children and individuals with chronic rhinosinusitis, allergic rhinitis, or upper respiratory tract infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of nasal irrigation with Nasir® on nasal cytology in children with allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation significantly reduced neutrophilic and eosinophilic infiltrates but did not significantly affect bacterial presence. The study suggests it may attenuate upper airway inflammation.
population_specificity: 66 children (40 males, 26 females, mean age 7.31±1.7 years, age range 4-17 years) with allergic rhinitis.
effective_dosage: One 250 mL sac of Nasir® solution twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of xylitol nasal irrigation (XNI) on chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) symptoms and its effect on nasal nitric oxide (NO) and iNOS mRNA levels in the maxillary sinus compared to saline nasal irrigation (SNI).
results_summary: XNI significantly reduced CRS symptoms (measured by VAS and SNOT-22) and increased nasal NO and iNOS mRNA levels in the maxillary sinus, while SNI showed no significant changes. The improvements were statistically greater in the XNI group compared to the SNI group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of nasal irrigation using saline at 25°C versus 40°C on clinical symptoms and inflammatory factors in patients with allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: The 40°C saline group showed a higher total effective rate (95.00%) compared to the 25°C group (76.67%), with significant improvements in nasal congestion and sneezing scores, as well as reduced histamine and leukotriene C4 levels. Runny nose and nasal itching scores did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: 120 patients with allergic rhinitis, divided into control (25°C saline) and experimental (40°C saline) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of postoperative budesonide nasal irrigation in reducing symptoms and oral steroid use in chronic rhinosinusitis patients with asthma.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in SNOT-22 and endoscopy scores, along with a substantial reduction in oral steroid intake after 6 months of budesonide nasal irrigation.
population_specificity: 12 chronic rhinosinusitis patients with nasal polyps and asthma who previously required oral steroids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-concentration hypochlorous acid (HOCl) nasal irrigation compared to saline placebo in improving symptoms of chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) refractory to medical therapy.
results_summary: HOCl irrigation significantly improved SNOT-20 scores by 2 weeks and RSDI scores by 1 week compared to saline, with sustained benefits at 4 weeks. Bacterial culture rates were lower in the HOCl group but not statistically significant, and endoscopic scores showed no difference between groups.
population_specificity: 43 adult patients (mean age 45.5 years) with chronic rhinosinusitis refractory to medical therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (low-concentration HOCl generated by a Salicid device).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nasal irrigation or steam inhalation, as pragmatic interventions, could effectively relieve sinus symptoms in adults with chronic or recurrent sinusitis.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation improved Rhinosinusitis Disability Index (RSDI) scores more than no irrigation by 3 months, with a clinically meaningful improvement maintained by 6 months. It also reduced the use of over-the-counter medications and future doctor consultations, while steam inhalation only reduced headache without significant effects on other outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with chronic or recurrent sinusitis and moderate-to-severe symptom impact on quality of life, recruited from UK primary care practices.
effective_dosage: Daily nasal saline irrigation (specific volume not stated).

study_goal: To study the effect of nasal irrigation in treating children with rhinosinusitis and compare its efficacy with different nasal irrigation methods and budesonide nasal spray.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation improved saccharin clearance time, nasal examination results, and quality of life in all groups, with the greatest improvement seen in the budesonide and saline irrigation group. Efficacy ranked as follows: budesonide nasal spray > 2.3% hypertonic saline > normal saline irrigation.
population_specificity: Children with rhinosinusitis (75 patients).
effective_dosage: Not specified (methods mention saline irrigation, budesonide nasal spray, and 2.3% hypertonic saline spray).
study_duration: Two weeks (evaluated at baseline, one week, and two weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether nasal irrigation with 100 μg/mL of amphotericin B (AMB) provided greater benefits than normal saline (NS) solution for postoperative care after functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) in chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) patients.
results_summary: The study found that while all patients reported improvement after nasal irrigation, there was no significant difference in outcomes between those who received AMB and those who received NS solution. AMB nasal irrigation did not confer additional benefits over NS in post-FESS care.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) who underwent FESS.
effective_dosage: 100 μg/mL of AMB or NS solution, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Draf III and Draf IIa frontal sinusotomy procedures in delivering topical therapies to the frontal sinus via nasal irrigation.
results_summary: Draf III was significantly superior to Draf IIa in achieving frontal sinus distribution of irrigation (90.6% vs. 50.1%). Vertex head position improved distribution synergistically with Draf III, but larger irrigation volumes only trended toward better distribution.
population_specificity: Fresh human cadaver heads (8 specimens, age 76 ± 11.2 years, 50% female).
effective_dosage: Pediatric (120 mL) and adult (240 mL) irrigation volumes with 1/1000 10% fluorescein-labeled free water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of isotonic (0.9%) and hypertonic (3%) saline nasal irrigation versus standard care on oxygen saturation and respiratory distress in infants with bronchiolitis.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation with isotonic saline significantly improved oxygen saturation compared to standard care at all measured time points, while hypertonic saline showed improvement only after 50 minutes. However, neither saline solution improved the WARM respiratory distress score.
population_specificity: Infants up to one year of age admitted to the emergency department with bronchiolitis and oxygen saturation (SpO2) between 88-94%.
effective_dosage: Single nasal irrigation with either 0.9% or 3% sodium chloride solution.
study_duration: Immediate effects measured up to 50 minutes post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-concentration hypochlorous acid (HOCl) nasal irrigation compared to isotonic normal saline for pediatric chronic rhinosinusitis.
results_summary: Both HOCl and normal saline nasal irrigation significantly improved total symptom scores, with no difference between the groups. X-ray scores improved in both groups, but the improvement was much greater in the HOCl group.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with chronic rhinosinusitis.

study_goal: To determine whether combining normal saline nasal irrigation with intranasal corticosteroids improves treatment outcomes for severe persistent allergic rhinitis compared to corticosteroids alone or with antihistamines.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation combined with intranasal corticosteroids was more effective than corticosteroids alone and nearly as effective as corticosteroids combined with antihistamines in reducing symptoms and improving quality of life for AR patients.
population_specificity: 273 outpatients with severe persistent allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate the optimization and efficacy of nasal irrigation protocols based on evidence-based literature.
results_summary: Large-volume low-pressure nasal irrigation with undiluted seawater was found to be the most effective protocol, optimizing distribution, cleansing power, mucociliary clearance, and epithelium trophicity. Ionic composition and pH, particularly alkaline pH and elevated calcium, improved ciliary motility, while bicarbonates, potassium, and magnesium enhanced healing and reduced inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general sinonasal pathologies and postoperative care).
effective_dosage: Large-volume low-pressure nasal irrigation with undiluted seawater (specific volume and frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of saline nasal irrigation on relieving symptoms of acute upper respiratory tract infections (URTIs).
results_summary: Most trials showed no significant difference between saline irrigation and control, but one larger trial in children reported modest reductions in nasal secretion and obstruction scores, along with decreased decongestant use. The overall evidence was limited by small sample sizes, high risk of bias, and inconsistent outcome measures.
population_specificity: Adults and children with clinically diagnosed acute URTIs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of nasal irrigation with saline (NI-S) or xylitol (NI-X) on sinus symptoms, fatigue, economic outcomes, and pro-inflammatory markers in Gulf War Illness (GWI) patients.
results_summary: Baseline data from the first 10 participants showed effective recruitment and data collection, but full results on efficacy are pending. The study anticipates robust analysis due to high participant adherence and data capture.
population_specificity: Gulf War veterans aged 35-65 with GWI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of nasal irrigation in improving symptoms of acute sinusitis in children.
results_summary: The study found no evidence to determine whether nasal irrigation is efficacious in children with acute sinusitis, as no trials met the inclusion criteria. Further research is needed to assess its benefits.
population_specificity: Children younger than 18 years with acute sinusitis (10-30 days of rhinorrhea, congestion, or daytime cough).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of amoxicillin with nasal irrigation versus nasal irrigation alone for treating acute sinusitis in children.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation with amoxicillin showed faster symptom relief initially, but no significant long-term difference was found between the two treatments. Antibiotic treatment provided only a small additional benefit over nasal irrigation alone.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-15 years with acute sinusitis.
effective_dosage: Saline nasal irrigation for 5 days, 0.25% phenylephrine for 2 days.
study_duration: 14 days for amoxicillin, 5 days for nasal irrigation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of nasal irrigation, nasal steroid spray, and their combination on symptoms and lower airway inflammation in patients with allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation improved nasal symptoms, quality of life, and reduced lower airway inflammation in allergic rhinitis patients. Combining nasal irrigation with nasal steroids showed more significant efficacy than either treatment alone.
population_specificity: 61 patients diagnosed with allergic rhinitis via skin prick test.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding large-volume, low-pressure nasal irrigation with saline to intranasal corticosteroid therapy improves quality of life and nasal breathing in allergic rhinitis patients compared to corticosteroid therapy alone.
results_summary: Nasal irrigation significantly improved quality of life (mRQLQ scores) but did not affect nasal peak inspiratory flow (NPIF) or nasal steroid use patterns. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with allergic rhinitis already on intranasal corticosteroid therapy.
effective_dosage: Large-volume, low-pressure saline irrigation twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of ovalbumin-flavonoids hydrogels on the thrombolytic activity and stability of nattokinase.
results_summary: The study found that nattokinase/ovalbumin-flavonoids hydrogels improved thrombolytic capacity, thermal stability, and pH stability compared to free nattokinase, with naringenin showing the strongest mechanical properties. Molecular interactions were primarily hydrogen bonds or hydrophobic interactions depending on the flavonoid.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of crude nattokinase extract (NCE) on the healing of acetic acid-induced oral mucositis in mice.
results_summary: NCE showed significantly higher fibrinolytic activity (10,800 U/ml) compared to other groups, promoted weight gain, and improved oral mucositis healing scores and histopathology outcomes more effectively than controls.
population_specificity: Mice with acetic acid-induced oral mucositis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if tofu processing wastewater could serve as a low-cost nitrogen source for nattokinase production using Bacillus subtilis, while addressing environmental pollution concerns.
results_summary: The study found that optimizing medium components and culture parameters increased nattokinase activity by 19.25%, with successful scale-up to 100 L bioreactors yielding high enzymatic activity (10,661.97 IU/mL).
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-scale fermentation using Bacillus subtilis 13932).
effective_dosage: Not specified (fermentation conditions: 37°C, pH 7.0, 70 mL liquid medium, 200 rpm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mixture containing nattokinase (AGM) improved glucose metabolism and insulin resistance in prediabetic adults.
results_summary: The AGM group showed significantly lower serum insulin concentrations and HOMA-IR index compared to placebo, suggesting improved insulin sensitivity. The mixture also reduced liver damage markers and inflammation, though glucose concentrations remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Prediabetic adults with fasting serum glucose concentrations of 100-140 mg/dL.
effective_dosage: 4 g of AGM granule (containing nattokinase at 0.1 w/w ratio) twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of nattokinase (100 mg/day) in patients admitted to vascular surgery for treating vascular diseases.
results_summary: Nattokinase improved clinical symptoms (p < 0.01) without adverse drug reactions or interactions, and no new cases of vascular diseases were recorded during follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients >18 years with vascular diseases (deep vein thrombosis, superficial vein thrombosis, venous insufficiency), naïve to anticoagulants or anti-platelets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-angiogenic effects of Nattokinase (NK) on retinal neovascularization and its potential mechanisms, including modulation of Nrf2/HO-1 signaling and glial activation.
results_summary: NK significantly reduced retinal neovascularization in an oxygen-induced retinopathy model, suppressed VEGF-induced endothelial cell proliferation and migration, and activated Nrf2/HO-1 pathways without toxicity in normal retinae. It also promoted microglial activation toward a reparative phenotype.
population_specificity: Oxygen-induced retinopathy murine model and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).

study_goal: To determine the effect of nattokinase on subclinical atherosclerosis progression and atherothrombotic biomarkers in individuals without clinical evidence of cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: Nattokinase supplementation showed no significant effect on subclinical atherosclerosis progression, blood pressure, or any laboratory measures compared to placebo. The study concluded that nattokinase had a null effect on these outcomes in healthy, low-risk individuals.
population_specificity: 265 individuals with a median age of 65.3 years, without clinical evidence of cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Nattokinase modified with polysialic acid (NK-PSA) could effectively clear cancer-associated thrombi (CAT) and improve nanoparticle drug delivery to tumors.
results_summary: NK-PSA enhanced the clearance rate of sialic acid-modified doxorubicin liposomes (DOX-SAL) and increased tumor accumulation of labeled SAL (DiR-SAL), leading to improved anti-tumor efficacy when combined with DOX-SAL.
population_specificity: Advanced tumors with cancer-associated thrombi (specific model not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the thrombolytic activities and underlying molecular mechanisms of NK-01 (a nattokinase-like protease) in relation to cardiovascular disease prevention and treatment.
results_summary: NK-01 inhibited coagulation factors, reduced blood pressure by affecting angiotensinogen and kininogen, and increased paraoxonase 1 to prevent atherosclerosis. The study identified key proteins involved in CVD-related metabolic processes.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo study, but no human or animal details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-thrombotic activity and safety of nattokinase with tissue-type plasminogen activator (t-PA) in a model of carotid arterial thrombosis.
results_summary: Nattokinase delayed thrombus formation and dissolved thrombi, showing near-full inhibition at 75 mg/kg, with a higher safety margin (4.0) compared to t-PA (1.2). Pulmonary hemorrhage occurred at higher doses (300 mg/kg), but combinational treatment with dexamethasone improved safety and efficacy.
population_specificity: Animal model (FeCl3-induced carotid arterial thrombosis)
interactions: Dexamethasone (2 mg/kg) improved safety and efficacy when combined with nattokinase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the acid resistance of Nattokinase (NK) to enhance its potential as an oral treatment for cardiovascular diseases.
results_summary: The study identified four single-point mutations (Q59E, S78T, Y217K, N218D) that improved NK's catalytic properties, acid stability, and thermostability, with one multipoint variant showing superior performance. Molecular dynamics simulations explained the stability mechanisms of S78T and Y217K mutants under acidic conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to produce a soluble, high-activity nattokinase in low-cost media with resistance to metal ions, detergents, and organic solvents for medical and industrial applications.
results_summary: The study successfully produced a recombinant nattokinase with high fibrinolytic activity (883.107 U/ml) using Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3) as a host, optimized media components, and calcium alginate entrapment to enhance enzyme activity and reduce costs.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Nattokinase (NK) could inhibit hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) tumor growth and improve survival in mouse models.
results_summary: Nattokinase crude extracts (NCE) increased survival rates by 31% in HCC-bearing mice, reduced tumor growth, and decreased markers like FOXM1, CD31, CD44, and vimentin.
population_specificity: Orthotopic HCC mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nattokinase supplementation alters hemostatic factors in hypercholesterolemic subjects.
results_summary: After 8 weeks, the nattokinase group showed significant increases in collagen-epinephrine closure time (C-EPI CT), prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) compared to placebo, indicating prolonged clotting times. The effects were statistically significant, particularly for C-EPI CT and aPTT.
population_specificity: Nondiabetic, borderline-to-moderate hypercholesterolemic subjects (serum cholesterol: 200-280 mg/dL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacologic effects of Nattokinase (NK) and its clinical relevance to cardiovascular disease (CVD).
results_summary: The study found that NK exhibits potent fibrinolytic activity, antihypertensive, anti-atherosclerotic, lipid-lowering, antiplatelet, and neuroprotective effects, suggesting it is a promising candidate for CVD prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular disease (CVD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance Nattokinase production in *Bacillus subtilis* WB800 using tandem promoters to improve its fibrinolytic activity for potential thrombosis therapy.
results_summary: The study found that tandem promoters, particularly PHpaII-PHpaII-PP43, significantly increased Nattokinase production, achieving a yield of 264.2 ± 7.0 FU/ml in small-scale and 816.7 ± 30.0 FU/ml in 5-L fermenter scale, surpassing previous reports.
population_specificity: *Bacillus subtilis* WB800 (microbial strain, not human subjects)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (production yield measured in FU/ml)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of PLGA-encapsulated nattokinase nanoparticles for treating Alzheimer's disease by assessing its antiamyloid and antifibrinolytic activities.
results_summary: The study found that PLGA-encapsulated nattokinase nanoparticles effectively downregulated amyloid aggregation and exhibited antifibrinolytic activity without compromising enzyme activity, suggesting potential as an AD treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo experimental study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and thrombolytic efficacy of a Nattokinase-TUDCA complex administered intravenously, focusing on reducing toxicity while maintaining therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The NK-TUDCA complex demonstrated lower toxicity in mice at tested dosages (130 kIU/kg acute, 13 kIU/kg repeated) and retained thrombolytic activity, with delayed release speculated as the mechanism for reduced toxicity.
population_specificity: Mice (animal study)
effective_dosage: 130 kIU/kg (acute toxicity test), 13 kIU/kg (repeated low-dose challenge)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the production, purification, and applications of Nattokinase, focusing on its fibrinolytic and thrombolytic properties for dietary and therapeutic use.
results_summary: The study highlights Nattokinase's strong fibrinolytic and thrombolytic activity, supporting its use as a dietary supplement for oral thrombolytic therapy and its potential in treating proliferative vitreoretinal disorders. It also discusses advancements in production and immobilization techniques to enhance industrial applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Nattokinase on nasal polyp tissues from patients with CRSwNP and its influence on mucus viscosity in nasal discharge and sputum from patients with CRSwNP and asthma.
results_summary: Nattokinase effectively shrunk nasal polyp tissue by degrading fibrin and significantly reduced the viscosity of nasal discharge and sputum in patients with CRSwNP and asthma.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps (CRSwNP) and subjects with asthma.
study_duration: 24 hours for nasal polyp tissue, 1 hour for nasal discharge and sputum

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate nattokinase's efficacy in reducing carotid artery intimal medial thickness and plaque size, lowering blood lipids, and exploring its mechanism of action compared to statins.
results_summary: Nattokinase significantly reduced carotid plaque size (36.6%) and CCA-IMT, outperforming statins (11.5%). It also improved HDL-C levels, though statins were more effective at lowering TC, LDL-C, and TG. The plaque reduction mechanism appeared independent of lipid-lowering effects.
population_specificity: Outpatients from the Department of TCM at the 3rd Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the history, benefits, safety, and production of Nattokinase (NK), including its potential for large-scale production and oral delivery.
results_summary: The study highlights NK's fibrinolytic (anti-clotting) capacity, its recognition in Western medicine, and ongoing clinical trials for atherothrombotic prevention. Recombinant technology and plant systems are promising for NK production and delivery.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the production of Nattokinase (NK) from Pseudomonas aeruginosa CMSS through media optimization and strain improvement.
results_summary: The study achieved a two-fold increase in NK activity (4263 U mL(-1)) via UV-mutagenesis, with the mutant strain showing 94% blood clot lysis in ten minutes and fibrin degradation within two hours. Optimal conditions included pH 7, 25°C, sucrose as carbon source, and shrimp shell powder as nitrogen source.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using bacterial strain P. aeruginosa CMSS isolated from cow milk).
effective_dosage: Not specified (activity measured in U mL(-1)).
study_duration: Not specified (experimental conditions described, but no intervention duration noted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether recombinant nattokinase expressed in E. coli could be refolded to achieve natural enzyme activity levels comparable to those from B. subtilis var. natto.
results_summary: The study found that refolding nattokinase inclusion bodies with specific refolding solutions (RS-10 and RS-11 at pH 9) restored fibrinolytic activity, achieving 79.3IU/mg, surpassing the activity of water-soluble proteins from B. subtilis var. natto (52.0IU/mg). Direct mixing with refolding solution yielded higher activity than traditional dilution methods.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (enzyme activity measured in IU/mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the quantitative effects of a single-dose of Nattokinase on coagulation and fibrinolysis parameters in healthy male subjects.
results_summary: The study found that a single-dose of Nattokinase significantly elevated D-dimer concentrations and fibrin/fibrinogen degradation products, reduced Factor VIII activity, increased antithrombin concentration, and prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time, all within normal ranges, suggesting enhanced fibrinolysis and anti-coagulation.
population_specificity: 12 healthy young males
study_duration: Single-dose administration with blood samples taken up to 8 hours post-administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the interaction between Nattokinase (NK) and heparin, as well as other glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), to understand NK's binding affinity and potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that NK is a heparin-binding protein with an affinity of ~250 nM, and the interaction is chain-length dependent, requiring a minimum heparin hexasaccharide. Chemically modified heparin studies revealed that 6-O-sulfo and N-sulfo groups are essential for binding, while 2-O-sulfo groups are not. NK also interfered with other heparin-protein interactions, such as those involving antithrombin and fibroblast growth factors.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
interactions: NK interacts with heparin and other GAGs (HS, DS, CSE) and interferes with heparin-protein interactions (e.g., antithrombin, fibroblast growth factors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the expression of nattokinase in Bacillus licheniformis for potential industrial production and therapeutic use in thrombus-related diseases.
results_summary: The study achieved high-level nattokinase expression by deleting protease genes and optimizing signal peptides, resulting in a 229% increase in fermentation activity compared to the original strain. The engineered strain reached commercial production levels, making it suitable for industrial use.
population_specificity: Bacterial strain (Bacillus licheniformis WX-02 and engineered variants)
effective_dosage: Not specified (measured in FU/mL and FU/g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Nattokinase's properties, production methods, and its potential applications in thrombolytic therapy and other conditions.
results_summary: The study highlights Nattokinase's fibrinolytic activity, stability in the gastrointestinal tract, and potential uses in treating hypertension, Alzheimer's disease, and vitreoretinal disorders. It also notes its safety and ease of mass production.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nattokinase (NK) could modulate factors associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathophysiology in an experimental rat model.
results_summary: NK administration significantly reduced brain acetylcholinesterase activity, TGF-β, Fas, and IL-6 levels, while increasing BDNF, IGF-1, and the expression of ADAM9 and ADAM10 genes, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for AD. Histological findings supported these biochemical improvements.
population_specificity: Male rats with induced Alzheimer's-like pathology.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only AlCl3 dosage mentioned: 17 mg/kg bw daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antihypertensive effects of GABA and nattokinase in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) compared to controls.
results_summary: The study found that GABA and nattokinase intake led to a definite decrease in systolic and diastolic blood pressure in SHR, with the greatest effect observed in the pharmacological treatment group. The fermented beans containing GABA and nattokinase showed potential for blood pressure control in hypertensive model animals.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) and Wistar-Kyoto (WKY) rats.
effective_dosage: High, medium, and low doses (specific amounts not provided).
study_duration: From the 8th to the 16th week of life (8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Nattokinase (subtilisin NAT) inhibits angiotensin I converting enzyme (ACE) and whether heat treatment enhances this effect, potentially contributing to blood pressure suppression.
results_summary: Nattokinase inhibited ACE, with heat treatment significantly enhancing this effect. The inhibition was mixed-type, involving reduced V(max) and increased K(m), and was attributed to ACE-inhibitory peptides (LY and FY) released upon heat-induced fragmentation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the antihypertensive effect of nattokinase is linked to its protease activity by comparing it with inactive fragments in spontaneously hypertensive rats.
results_summary: High-dosage nattokinase significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure and plasma fibrinogen levels without affecting the renin-angiotensin system, while inactive fragments reduced blood pressure and plasma angiotensin II levels but not fibrinogen.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR)
effective_dosage: Nattokinase (0.2, 2.6 mg/g diet); fragments (0.2, 0.6 mg/g diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to detect nattokinase in human blood after ingestion, confirm its presence immunologically, and establish a pharmacokinetic profile.
results_summary: Nattokinase was detected in human serum, with peak levels at ~13.3 hours post-ingestion, and statistically significant increases in binding were observed from baseline up to 24 hours. The study suggests further pharmacokinetic research is needed.
population_specificity: 11 healthy participants (5 male, 6 female, ages 21-65).
effective_dosage: Single daily dose of 2000 FU (100 mg nattokinase per capsule).
study_duration: 48 hours (blood draws over 24 hours, with follow-up at 48 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the fibrinolytic activity of nattokinase using DNA family shuffling and assess its potential for thrombolytic therapy.
results_summary: The study successfully generated a mutant nattokinase with 16 amino acid substitutions, showing 2.3 times higher catalytic efficiency than the wild-type enzyme. Molecular modeling suggested the mutations altered the substrate-binding pocket's surface conformation, enhancing enzymatic function.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the amyloid-degrading ability of nattokinase and identify the optimal conditions for amyloid hydrolysis.
results_summary: The study found that nattokinase, along with proteinase K and subtilisin Carlsberg, can degrade amyloid fibrils, but trypsin and plasmin cannot. The research suggests potential therapeutic applications for amyloid-related diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of nattokinase supplementation on blood pressure in individuals with pre-hypertension or stage 1 hypertension.
results_summary: Nattokinase supplementation significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to placebo, with net changes of -5.55 mmHg and -2.84 mmHg, respectively, and also lowered renin activity. The findings suggest nattokinase may help prevent and treat hypertension.
population_specificity: Adults aged 20-80 with untreated systolic blood pressure of 130-159 mmHg (pre-hypertension or stage 1 hypertension).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the purification and concentration of nattokinase from fermentation broth using reverse micelles extraction and evaluate its fibrinolytic potential.
results_summary: The study found that nattokinase could be purified with 80% activity recovery and a purification factor of 3.9, achieving an eight-fold enrichment during backward extraction. Optimal temperatures for forward and backward extraction were 25°C and 35°C, respectively, though the enzyme became more thermosensitive during the process.
